elements.content: Hydrothermal reactions of lanthanide(III) chlorides and H2O3PCH2NCH2(CH2CH2OPO2H) (H3L) with oxalate anion lead to six novel lanthanide oxalatophosphonates with a three-dimensional (3D) framework structure, namely, {[Ln(H2L)(C2O4)(H2O)]·nH2O}∞ [n = 3 (compounds 1–3), 2 (compounds 4–6); Ln = Ce (1), Pr (2), Nd (3), Sm (4), Eu (5), and Tb(6)]. Compounds 1–6 are isostructural and feature a complex 3D network built from 1D chains of lanthanide oxalate and {Ln(H2L)}2+ chains. These lanthanide oxalatophosphonates possess two types of channels with dimensions of 11.6 Å × 4.4 Å and 13.8 Å × 8.9 Å along the a- and b-axis, respectively, and these channels incorporate some crystalline water molecules therein by hydrogen-bonding interactions. They show an unusual noninterpenetrated (3,5)-connected topology. The title compounds were characterized by X-ray single-crystal diffraction and X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) as well as with infrared spectroscopy and elemental and thermogravimetric analysis. Furthermore, the temperature-dependent powder XRD, the variable temperature IR spectroscopy, and the dehydration/hydration properties of compound 2 have also been studied. Luminescent measurements indicate that the Sm (4) and Eu (5) compounds exhibit strong luminescence in yellow light and red light regions, respectively.

elements.content: The research field on metal phosphonates has been deeply explored during the last two decades because of the great variety of building blocks available for the preparation of functional materials useful in the field of molecular recognition, gas storage, and materials chemistry and for their photochemistry and magnetic properties. The strategy of attaching functional groups such as crown ether, amine, hydroxyl, and carboxylate groups to the phosphonic acid has made the scientific literature in this field more and more rich, and still today, the research for new polyfunctional phosphonates is far from being exhausted. Subsequently, a large number of metal phosphonates with polynuclear cluster, chain, layer, and 3D framework structures have been obtained in our and other groups. Recently, lanthanide compounds with organic ligands are of current research interest for their new structure types and excellent luminescent and magnetic properties. In particular, organophosphonate has been exploited to be one of the most attractive ligands for building lanthanide-containing materials because of their versatile coordination modes as well as the good thermal and chemical stabilities of the Ln–O–P bonds that phosphonate ligands made with lanthanide ions. However, in that review, it has been pointed out that the number of structurally characterized lanthanide phosphonates is relatively low because of the general high insolubility of these derivatives in water and organic solvents, making difficult the obtainment of single crystals. The problem can be solved by two methods: (1) employing phosphonate ligands containing functional groups, such as amine, hydroxyl, carboxylate, pyridyl, and sulfonate groups, etc., and (2) introducing a second ligand such as 1,10-phenanthroline or carboxylic acid. By using the above two approaches, a lot of fascinating examples have been made by Clearfield, Férey, Stock, and Lin et al., and a series of lanthanide phosphonates with carboxylic acid as a second ligand have been reported by Mao's group. Recently, many research activities have been concerned with the synthesis of hybrid frameworks by incorporating a second organic ligand such as oxalate, sulfonic acids, 2,2′-bipyridine, 4,4′-bipyridine, or 1,10-phenanthroline into the structures of metal phosphonates because of their interesting structures and potential applications. The results from our present investigation indicate that oxalate is a good candidate as a second metal linker in the synthesis of metal phosphonates with novel structure types and fluorescent properties. It is well-known that oxalate is able to mediate electronic effects between paramagnetic metal ions. It can also act as a linker between metal centers to yield structures ranging from zero-dimensional species to three-dimensional (3D) open frameworks. Furthermore, the coordination of two types of ligands with the lanthanide ion may reduce or eliminate water molecules from the coordination sphere of the lanthanide(III) ion, hence increasing the luminescent intensity and lifetime of the materials. Our interest in metal phosphonate chemistry has also been extended to the lanthanide compounds in recent years. By using organophosphonic acids as the ligands, C2O4 2– as the second metal linker, a series of novel lanthanide oxalatophosphonate hybrids with different architectures have been obtained by our group. As an expansion of our work on lanthanide phosphonates, we selected H2O3PCH2NCH2(CH2CH2OPO2H) (H3L) as the phosphonate ligand (Scheme a) and oxalate as the second metal linker. Hydrothermal reactions of the above two ligands with lanthanide(III) chlorides afforded six novel lanthanide oxalatophosphonates hybrids with a 3D framework structure, namely, {[Ln(H2L)(C2O4)(H2O)]·nH2O}∞ [n = 3 (compounds 1–3), 2 (compounds 4–6); Ln = Ce (1), Pr (2), Nd (3), Sm (4), Eu (5), and Tb (6)]. Their structures are quite different from those reported by our group in the gadolinium(III) carboxyphosphonate, where the same organophosphonic acid (H3L) is employed. Herein, we report their syntheses, crystal structures, thermal stabilities, and dehydration/hydration properties. The luminescence properties of compounds 4 and 5 have also been studied.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The research field on metal phosphonates has been deeply explored during the last two decades because of the great variety of building blocks available for the preparation of functional materials useful in the field of molecular recognition, gas storage, and materials chemistry and for their photochemistry and magnetic properties. The strategy of attaching functional groups such as crown ether, amine, hydroxyl, and carboxylate groups to the phosphonic acid has made the scientific literature in this field more and more rich, and still today, the research for new polyfunctional phosphonates is far from being exhausted. Subsequently, a large number of metal phosphonates with polynuclear cluster, chain, layer, and 3D framework structures have been obtained in our and other groups. Recently, lanthanide compounds with organic ligands are of current research interest for their new structure types and excellent luminescent and magnetic properties. In particular, organophosphonate has been exploited to be one of the most attractive ligands for building lanthanide-containing materials because of their versatile coordination modes as well as the good thermal and chemical stabilities of the Ln-O-P bonds that phosphonate ligands made with lanthanide ions. However, in that review, it has been pointed out that the number of structurally characterized lanthanide phosphonates is relatively low because of the general high insolubility of these derivatives in water and organic solvents, making difficult the obtainment of single crystals. The problem can be solved by two methods: (1) employing phosphonate ligands containing functional groups, such as amine, hydroxyl, carboxylate, pyridyl, and sulfonate groups, etc., and (2) introducing a second ligand such as 1,10-phenanthroline or carboxylic acid. By using the above two approaches, a lot of fascinating examples have been made by Clearfield, Férey, Stock, and Lin et al., and a series of lanthanide phosphonates with carboxylic acid as a second ligand have been reported by Mao's group. Recently, many research activities have been concerned with the synthesis of hybrid frameworks by incorporating a second organic ligand such as oxalate, sulfonic acids, 2,2'-bipyridine, 4,4'-bipyridine, or 1,10-phenanthroline into the structures of metal phosphonates because of their interesting structures and potential applications. The results from our present investigation indicate that oxalate is a good candidate as a second metal linker in the synthesis of metal phosphonates with novel structure types and fluorescent properties. It is well-known that oxalate is able to mediate electronic effects between paramagnetic metal ions. It can also act as a linker between metal centers to yield structures ranging from zero-dimensional species to three-dimensional (3D) open frameworks. Furthermore, the coordination of two types of ligands with the lanthanide ion may reduce or eliminate water molecules from the coordination sphere of the lanthanide(III) ion, hence increasing the luminescent intensity and lifetime of the materials. Our interest in metal phosphonate chemistry has also been extended to the lanthanide compounds in recent years. By using organophosphonic acids as the ligands, C2O4 2- as the second metal linker, a series of novel lanthanide oxalatophosphonate hybrids with different architectures have been obtained by our group. As an expansion of our work on lanthanide phosphonates, we selected H2O3PCH2NCH2(CH2CH2OPO2H) (H3L) as the phosphonate ligand (Scheme a) and oxalate as the second metal linker. Hydrothermal reactions of the above two ligands with lanthanide(III) chlorides afforded six novel lanthanide oxalatophosphonates hybrids with a 3D framework structure, namely, {[Ln(H2L)(C2O4)(H2O)]⋅nH2O}∞ [n = 3 (compounds 1-3), 2 (compounds 4-6); Ln = Ce (1), Pr (2), Nd (3), Sm (4), Eu (5), and Tb (6)]. Their structures are quite different from those reported by our group in the gadolinium(III) carboxyphosphonate, where the same organophosphonic acid (H3L) is employed. Herein, we report their syntheses, crystal structures, thermal stabilities, and dehydration/hydration properties. The luminescence properties of compounds 4 and 5 have also been studied.

elements.content: The organophosphonic acid, H2O3PCH2NCH2(CH2CH2OPO2H) (H3L), was prepared by a Mannich type reaction according to procedures described previously. The lanthanide(III) chlorides were prepared by dissolving corresponding lanthanide oxides (General Research Institute for Nonferrous Metals, 99.99%) in hydrochloric acid followed by recrystallization and drying. All other chemicals were used as obtained without further purification. C, H, and N were determined by using a PE-2400 elemental analyzer. Ce, Pr, Nd, Sm, Eu, Tb, and P were determined by using an inductively coupled plasma (ICP) atomic absorption spectrometer. IR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Tensor-27 FT-IR spectrometer with KBr pellets in the range 400–4000 cm–1. The X-ray powder diffraction data were collected on a Bruker AXS D8 Advance diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) in the 2θ range of 5–60° with a step size of 0.02° and a scanning rate of 3°/min. Thermogravimetric (TG) analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer Pyris Diamond TG-DTA thermal analysis system in static air with a heating rate of 10 K min–1 from 50 to 1100 °C. The luminescence spectra were reported on a HITACHI F-7000 spectrofluorimeter (solid).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

The organophosphonic acid, H2O3PCH2NCH2(CH2CH2OPO2H) (H3L), was prepared by a Mannich type reaction according to procedures described previously. The lanthanide(III) chlorides were prepared by dissolving corresponding lanthanide oxides (General Research Institute for Nonferrous Metals, 99.99%) in hydrochloric acid followed by recrystallization and drying. All other chemicals were used as obtained without further purification. C, H, and N were determined by using a PE-2400 elemental analyzer. Ce, Pr, Nd, Sm, Eu, Tb, and P were determined by using an inductively coupled plasma (ICP) atomic absorption spectrometer. IR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Tensor-27 FT-IR spectrometer with KBr pellets in the range 400-4000 cm-1. The X-ray powder diffraction data were collected on a Bruker AXS D8 Advance diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) in the 2θ range of 5-60° with a step size of 0.02° and a scanning rate of 3°/min. Thermogravimetric (TG) analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer Pyris Diamond TG-DTA thermal analysis system in static air with a heating rate of 10 K min-1 from 50 to 1100 °C. The luminescence spectra were reported on a HITACHI F-7000 spectrofluorimeter (solid).

elements.content: A mixture of CeCl3·7H2O (0.19 g, 0.5 mmol), H3L (0.26 g, 1.0 mmol), H2C2O4·2H2O (0.25 g, 2.0 mmol), and NaOH (0.08 g, 2.0 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of distilled water. The resulting solution was stirred for about 1 h at room temperature, sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, and then heated at 180 °C for 4 days. After the mixture was cooled slowly to room temperature, the colorless block crystals were obtained. Yield: 61.2% based on Ce. Anal. calcd for C6H18NO14P2Ce: C, 13.59; H, 3.42; N, 2.64; P, 11.68; Ce, 26.42. Found: C, 13.65; H, 3.46; N, 2.68; P, 11.61; Ce, 26.38%. elements.content: Data collections for compounds 1–6 were performed on the Bruker AXS Smart APEX II CCD X-diffractometer equipped with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293 ± 2 K. An empirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full matrix least-squares on F 2 by using the programs SHELXS-97. All nonhydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms except those for water molecules were generated geometrically with fixed isotropic thermal parameters and included in the structure factor calculations. Hydrogen atoms for water molecules were not included in the refinement. Details of crystallographic data of compounds 1–6 are summarized in Table . Selected bond distances and angles of compounds 1–6 are listed in Table . Hydrogen bonds for compound 2 are listed in Table .

X-ray Crystallography

Data collections for compounds 1-6 were performed on the Bruker AXS Smart APEX II CCD X-diffractometer equipped with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293 ± 2 K. An empirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full matrix least-squares on F 2 by using the programs SHELXS-97. All nonhydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms except those for water molecules were generated geometrically with fixed isotropic thermal parameters and included in the structure factor calculations. Hydrogen atoms for water molecules were not included in the refinement. Details of crystallographic data of compounds 1-6 are summarized in Table . Selected bond distances and angles of compounds 1-6 are listed in Table . Hydrogen bonds for compound 2 are listed in Table .

The title compounds are formed by a hydrothermal reaction, using the H2­O3­PCH2­NCH2­(CH2­CH2­OPO2H) (H3L) as the phosphonate ligand and oxalate as the second ligand. In an attempt to produce single phase materials, the optimal conditions of synthesizing were explored. NaOH was added into the reaction system directly in the form of solid to adjust the pH of the reaction mixture. It was found that the reaction temperature plays an important role in the formation of six compounds. Compounds 1–5 were obtained as a single phase at the used reaction temperature of 180 °C, while compound 6 was obtained at 120 °C. In addition, the molar ratio of the starting materials also has a strong effect on the formation of the title compounds. The best crystals of compounds 1–5 were observed for the molar ratio Ln3+/H3L/H2C2O4·2H2O/NaOH = 1:2:4:4. However, we try to prepare compound 6 following the same molar ratio to that of compounds 1–5. The amorphous white powders were obtained, which was indicated by X-ray powder diffraction analysis. Finally, compound 6 was observed in regions with the molar ratio Ln3+/H3L/H2C2O4·2H2O/NaOH = 1:2:8:8. Although compound 6 could be prepared repeatedly, the yield is very low, and only the crystal structure for compound 6 was recorded; its TGA, IR, luminescence, elemental analysis, and XRD powder diffraction studies were not performed. A lot of efforts were tried to synthesize the sufficient products of compound 6, such as changing the H3L/Ln ratios, pH values, and the reaction temperatures, but were unsuccessful. The powder X-ray diffraction patterns (PXRD) of compounds 1–5 all match those simulated from single-crystal X-ray data, clearly indicating that the pure phases are obtained (Figure S1 in the ).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses

The title compounds are formed by a hydrothermal reaction, using the H2O3PCH2NCH2(CH2CH2OPO2H) (H3L) as the phosphonate ligand and oxalate as the second ligand. In an attempt to produce single phase materials, the optimal conditions of synthesizing were explored. NaOH was added into the reaction system directly in the form of solid to adjust the pH of the reaction mixture. It was found that the reaction temperature plays an important role in the formation of six compounds. Compounds 1-5 were obtained as a single phase at the used reaction temperature of 180 °C, while compound 6 was obtained at 120 °C. In addition, the molar ratio of the starting materials also has a strong effect on the formation of the title compounds. The best crystals of compounds 1-5 were observed for the molar ratio Ln3+/H3L/H2C2O4⋅2H2O/NaOH = 1:2:4:4. However, we try to prepare compound 6 following the same molar ratio to that of compounds 1-5. The amorphous white powders were obtained, which was indicated by X-ray powder diffraction analysis. Finally, compound 6 was observed in regions with the molar ratio Ln3+/H3L/H2C2O4⋅2H2O/NaOH = 1:2:8:8. Although compound 6 could be prepared repeatedly, the yield is very low, and only the crystal structure for compound 6 was recorded; its TGA, IR, luminescence, elemental analysis, and XRD powder diffraction studies were not performed. A lot of efforts were tried to synthesize the sufficient products of compound 6, such as changing the H3L/Ln ratios, pH values, and the reaction temperatures, but were unsuccessful. The powder X-ray diffraction patterns (PXRD) of compounds 1-5 all match those simulated from single-crystal X-ray data, clearly indicating that the pure phases are obtained (Figure S1 in the ).

elements.content: Compounds 1–6 are isomorphous and feature a three-dimensional open framework structure. Hence, only the structure of compound 2 will be described in detail as an example. The building unit of compound 2 consists of one crystallographically independent Pr(III) ion, one partly deprotonated H2L– anion, one C2O4 2– anion, one coordination water molecule, and three lattice water molecules (Figure ). The Pr(III) ion exhibits an eight-coordinated environment. Three of the eight coordination positions are filled with three phosphonate oxygen atoms (O1, O3A, and O5B) from three separate H2L– anions. The remaining sites are occupied by four carboxyl oxygen atoms (O7, O8C, O9, and O10C) from two C2O4 2– anions and one coordianted water molecule (O11). The coordination geometry around the Pr(III) ion can be viewed as a distorted bicapped trigonal prism. The oxygen atoms O3A, O5B, O7, O8C, O10C, and O11 form a trigonal prism, whereas O1 and O9 act as capping atoms. The bond lengths of Pr–O are in the range of 2.373(4) to 2.555(4) Å, which are comparable to those reported for other Pr(III) phosphonates. The oxalate anion adopts the most commonly observed bis-bidentate coordination mode, chelating to two Pr(III) ions forming two Pr–O–C–C–O five-membered chelating rings (Scheme b). The H2L– anion functions as a tridentate ligand and bridges with three Pr(III) ions through three phosphonate oxygen atoms (O1, O3, and O5). One phosphonate oxygen atom (O6) is protonated, additionally, based on the charge balance, and the nitrogen atom is also protonated (Scheme c). It is noted that the PrO8 polyhedra are elongated along one bond, with the water molecule Pr–O11 bond being the longest; the phosphate tetrahedra are elongated along the P–C bond, and the difference in bond lengths between the P–O and P–C bonds is greater for the phosphate tetrahedra with the protonated oxygen (O6) (see Table ).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures of 1-6 

Compounds 1-6 are isomorphous and feature a three-dimensional open framework structure. Hence, only the structure of compound 2 will be described in detail as an example. The building unit of compound 2 consists of one crystallographically independent Pr(III) ion, one partly deprotonated H2L- anion, one C2O4 2- anion, one coordination water molecule, and three lattice water molecules (Figure ). The Pr(III) ion exhibits an eight-coordinated environment. Three of the eight coordination positions are filled with three phosphonate oxygen atoms (O1, O3A, and O5B) from three separate H2L- anions. The remaining sites are occupied by four carboxyl oxygen atoms (O7, O8C, O9, and O10C) from two C2O4 2- anions and one coordianted water molecule (O11). The coordination geometry around the Pr(III) ion can be viewed as a distorted bicapped trigonal prism. The oxygen atoms O3A, O5B, O7, O8C, O10C, and O11 form a trigonal prism, whereas O1 and O9 act as capping atoms. The bond lengths of Pr-O are in the range of 2.373(4) to 2.555(4) Å, which are comparable to those reported for other Pr(III) phosphonates. The oxalate anion adopts the most commonly observed bis-bidentate coordination mode, chelating to two Pr(III) ions forming two Pr-O-C-C-O five-membered chelating rings (Scheme b). The H2L- anion functions as a tridentate ligand and bridges with three Pr(III) ions through three phosphonate oxygen atoms (O1, O3, and O5). One phosphonate oxygen atom (O6) is protonated, additionally, based on the charge balance, and the nitrogen atom is also protonated (Scheme c). It is noted that the PrO8 polyhedra are elongated along one bond, with the water molecule Pr-O11 bond being the longest; the phosphate tetrahedra are elongated along the P-C bond, and the difference in bond lengths between the P-O and P-C bonds is greater for the phosphate tetrahedra with the protonated oxygen (O6) (see Table ).

elements.content: The Pr(III) ions are bridged by H2L– anions to form a 1D double chain of {Pr(H2L)}2+ along the a-axis (Figure a). The interconnection of the Pr(III) ions by chelating oxalate anions leads to an infinite zigzag chain of {Pr(C2O4)}+ along the b-axis (Figure b). The above two types of chains are interconnected via sharing Pr(III) ions to form a 3D framework structure (Figure c). The result of connections in this manner is the formation of a channel system along the b-axis. The channel is assembled by 30-atom rings, which consist of five Pr(III) ions, three H2L– anions, and two oxalate anions. The size of the channel is estimated to be 13.8 Å (Pr1–C1) × 8.9 Å (C3–O7) on the basis of structure data (Figure d). Viewed down the a-axis (Figure a), the framework of compound 2 also displays long narrowshaped tunnels composed of 24-atom rings formed by six Pr(III) ions, two H2L– anions, and four oxalate anions [size about 11.6 Å (C6–C6) × 4.4 Å (P1–O8)] (Figure b). It is noteworthy that the lattice water molecules are located at the above apertures and form strong hydrogen bonds with the coordination water molecules, phosphonate oxygens, and carboxyl oxygen atoms with O···O distances of 3.203(11) Å, O(2W)–H(2WA)···O(6); 2.482(6) Å, O(6)–H(6A)···O(1W); 2.729(11) Å, O(11)–H(11A)···O(3W); 3.253(6) Å, O(11)–H(11B)···O(1)a; and 2.675(5) Å, O(1W)–H(1WB)···O(4)b (symmetry code: a, −x + 3, −y + 1, −z + 1; b, −x + 2, y – 1/2, −z + 1/2), respectively. The nitrogen atom (N1) also forms a hydrogen bond with a phosphonate oxygen atom (O4): N(1)–H(1C)···O(4)c (symmetry code: c, −x + 2, −y + 2, −z + 1), and the bond distances is 2.677(5) Å. These strong hydrogen bonds enhance the stability of the network and affect the crystal packing of the molecules. The solvent-accessible volume in compound 2 is calculated to be about 10.3% by using the PLATON program.

elements.content: For a clearer representation, the whole structure can be achieved by the application of a topological approach. We examined the connection mode of the metal centers and organic ligands. Each Pr(III) ion is linked by three H2L– anions and two oxalate anions, and each H2L– anion bridges to three Pr(III) atoms. If we simplify the oxalate anions as sticks, the Pr(III) ion can be considered to be a five-connected node, and the H2L– anion can act as a three-connected node. Therefore, the framework can be described as an unusual noninterpenetrated (3,5)-connected network (Figure ). To the best of our knowledge and searching in Reticular Chemistry Structure Resource (http://rcsr.anu.edu.au/rcsr_nets/search/), this type of net has not been reported before.

elements.content: It is worth noting that the framework structure of compounds 1–6 is quite different from that of [Gd2­{OCH2­CH2­NH­(CH2­PO3H)­(CH2­PO2)}­(C2O4)2.5­(H2O)2]·­5H2O incorporating the same H3L ligand, which has been reported by our group previously. In the latter case, the interconnection of the Gd(III) ions by chelating and bridging oxalate anions leads to a 3D network of [Gd2(C2O4)2.5]+, which are further interconnected by phosphonate groups to form a 3D open-framework structure. While in compounds 1–6, the 3D framework structure is built from 1D chains of lanthanide oxalate and {Ln(H2L)}2+ chains. The differences between the two structures arise in the different coordination modes of H3L ligand (Scheme c for compounds 1–6 and Scheme d for [Gd2{OCH2CH2NH(CH2PO3H)(CH2PO2)}(C2O4)2.5(H2O)2]·5H2O). Furthermore, the number of the coordinated oxalate anions also plays an important role in the formation of these two different structural types. The main reason for the difference of the structures may be related to the different reaction conditions. From the above results, we conclude that by introduction of oxalate as the second ligand, we can obtain different types of lanthanide oxalatophosphonates with novel crystal structures.

In the latter case, the interconnection of the Gd(III) ions by chelating and bridging oxalate anions leads to a 3D network of [Gd2(C2O4)2.5]+, which are further interconnected by phosphonate groups to form a 3D open-framework structure. While in compounds 1-6, the 3D framework structure is built from 1D chains of lanthanide oxalate and {Ln(H2L)}2+ chains. The differences between the two structures arise in the different coordination modes of H3L ligand (Scheme c for compounds 1-6 and Scheme d for [Gd2{OCH2CH2NH(CH2PO3H)(CH2PO2)}(C2O4)2.5(H2O)2]⋅5H2O). From the above results, we conclude that by introduction of oxalate as the second ligand, we can obtain different types of lanthanide oxalatophosphonates with novel crystal structures.

elements.content: It is observed that the decrease of the lattice parameters and the Ln–O bond lengths from compounds 1 to 6 is due to the so-called “lanthanide contraction”. The correlation between the ionic radii and the lattice constants is shown in Figure . When compared to unit-cell parameters and volume of the cerium compound, the normalized unit-cell parameters and volumes, a/a Ce, b/b Ce, β/βCe, and V/V Ce, are found to increase with the ionic radii of the lanthanide cation increasing. However, the slight decrease of the c-axis with the cation in compounds 1–6, which is due to the slight distortions of the polyhedra versus the lanthanide atom.
elements.clean_text:
Lattice Constants Correlation

It is observed that the decrease of the lattice parameters and the Ln-O bond lengths from compounds 1 to 6 is due to the so-called "lanthanide contraction". The correlation between the ionic radii and the lattice constants is shown in Figure . When compared to unit-cell parameters and volume of the cerium compound, the normalized unit-cell parameters and volumes, a/a Ce, b/b Ce, β/βCe, and V/V Ce, are found to increase with the ionic radii of the lanthanide cation increasing. However, the slight decrease of the c-axis with the cation in compounds 1-6, which is due to the slight distortions of the polyhedra versus the lanthanide atom.

elements.content: The IR spectra of compounds 1–5 have many similar features corresponding to the common groups; thus, only the spectrum of compound 2 will be discussed (Figure S2 in the ). The IR spectra for all of the as-synthesized compounds were recorded in the region 400–4000 cm–1. The bands in the range of 3100–3500 cm–1 and the medium band at around 1670 cm–1 confirm the presence of water molecules in compound 2. The position and width suggest that it is loosely bonded and that interactions through hydrogen bonds are present. The sharp band at 3409 cm–1 can be assigned to the O–H stretching vibration of water molecules coordinated to Pr3+ ions. The weak band at 3017 cm–1 is attributed to the N–H stretching vibrations. Sharp bands of low intensity at around 2960 cm–1 are due to CH2 stretching vibrations. The sharp band observed at 2705 cm–1 and one pair of week bands centered at 2592 and 2475 cm–1, which are likely due to ν(P–OH) and the overtone 2δ(P–O–H), respectively, are characteristic of hydrogen phosphonate groups. The coordination of the carboxylate function is seen by a shift from the expected value for the uncoordinated carboxylic acid [ν(C–O) typically around 1700–1725 cm–1] to values of 1596 and 1480 cm–1, which are assigned to the asymmetrical and symmetrical stretching vibrations of C–O groups when present as COO– moieties. The bands at 1448 and 1418 cm–1 are due to the C–P stretching vibrations. The bending vibration of C–H is located at around 1320 cm–1. Strong bands between 1200 and 900 cm–1 are due to stretching vibrations of the tetrahedral CPO3 groups, as expected. Additional intensive and sharp bands at low energy are found. These bands are probably due to bending vibrations of the tetrahedral CPO3 groups.

The sharp band at 3409 cm-1 can be assigned to the O-H stretching vibration of water molecules coordinated to Pr3+ ions. The weak band at 3017 cm-1 is attributed to the N-H stretching vibrations. Sharp bands of low intensity at around 2960 cm-1 are due to CH2 stretching vibrations. The sharp band observed at 2705 cm-1 and one pair of week bands centered at 2592 and 2475 cm-1, which are likely due to ν(P-OH) and the overtone 2δ(P-O-H), respectively, are characteristic of hydrogen phosphonate groups. The coordination of the carboxylate function is seen by a shift from the expected value for the uncoordinated carboxylic acid [ν(C-O) typically around 1700-1725 cm-1] to values of 1596 and 1480 cm-1, which are assigned to the asymmetrical and symmetrical stretching vibrations of C-O groups when present as COO- moieties. elements.content: Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out in the interest of studying the thermal behaviors of the open-framework polymer materials. The experiments were performed in static air for crystalline samples of compounds 1–5 in the temperature range from 50 to 1100 °C. Compounds 1–5 show similar thermal decomposition process with four main continuous weight losses. Herein, we use compound 2 as an example to illuminate the weight losses in detail (Figure S3 in the ). The water molecules are released in two steps. The first step started at 50 °C and was completed at 105 °C, corresponding to the release of one water molecule. A weight loss of 3.1% is observed, which is in good agreement with the calculated value (3.4%). The remaining three water molecules are released up to 200 °C, and the observed weight loss of 7.8% is smaller than the calculated value (10.1%). The third step, from 340 to 405 °C, corresponds to the partly decomposition of oxalate and phosphonate units. The fourth step covers a temperature range from 965 to 1020 °C, which can be attributed to the further decomposition of the organic groups in the framework, leaving purely inorganic praseodymium phosphate network. The final product of the thermal process is the mixture of Pr(PO3)3 and PrPO4 on the basis of powder X-ray diffraction (Figure S4 in the ). The total weight loss of 40.7% is slightly smaller than the calculated value (42.2%).
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analysis

Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out in the interest of studying the thermal behaviors of the open-framework polymer materials. The experiments were performed in static air for crystalline samples of compounds 1-5 in the temperature range from 50 to 1100 °C. Compounds 1-5 show similar thermal decomposition process with four main continuous weight losses. Herein, we use compound 2 as an example to illuminate the weight losses in detail (Figure S3 in the ). The water molecules are released in two steps. The first step started at 50 °C and was completed at 105 °C, corresponding to the release of one water molecule. A weight loss of 3.1% is observed, which is in good agreement with the calculated value (3.4%). The remaining three water molecules are released up to 200 °C, and the observed weight loss of 7.8% is smaller than the calculated value (10.1%). The third step, from 340 to 405 °C, corresponds to the partly decomposition of oxalate and phosphonate units. The fourth step covers a temperature range from 965 to 1020 °C, which can be attributed to the further decomposition of the organic groups in the framework, leaving purely inorganic praseodymium phosphate network. The final product of the thermal process is the mixture of Pr(PO3)3 and PrPO4 on the basis of powder X-ray diffraction (Figure S4 in the ). The total weight loss of 40.7% is slightly smaller than the calculated value (42.2%).

elements.content: To further investigate the thermal stability and phase transformation of the synthesized materials, compound 2 was calcined at different temperatures, and the temperature-dependent powder XRD (Figure S5 in the ) as well as the variable temperature IR spectra (Figure S6 in the ) were studied. For compound 2, from room temperature to 180 °C, almost no change occurs, and the powder patterns are in agreement with the theoretical pattern of the title compounds. When the temperature is increased to 200 °C, the diffraction peaks occur an obvious change. We assume that the structure transformation is due to the release of all water molecules. These findings are in good agreement with the variable temperature IR spectroscopy. The IR spectra of the calcined samples at 120 and 180 °C are similar to those of the initial sample. However, the typical bands of the water molecules could not be observed from the infrared spectroscopy at higher temperature (200 °C), which indicate that all four water molecules release from the initial compounds. Meanwhile, these are also consistent with the TG results. On increasing the temperature further, the sample becomes amorphous at the range of 340–550 °C. Moreover, for the calcined samples at 340, 420, and 550 °C, the IR spectra do not display the peaks at 1596 and 1480 cm–1 due to ν(C–O) of the oxalate and the weak peaks at 1448 and 1418 cm–1 due to ν(C–P) of the CPO3 group. Therefore, the partial loss of the oxalate and phosphonate units above 340 °C is confirmed. To identify the final decomposition products, a separate sample was heated at higher temperatures (for example, 650 °C), and the XRD pattern corresponds to the mixture of Pr(PO3)3 and PrPO4. From what has been discussed above, we can indicate that the theoretical results of the TG are consistent with the experimental results.

elements.content: To study the dehydration/hydration properties of these compounds, compound 2 was heated to different temperatures (120 and 200 °C) for 3 h and then was treated with water (Figure S7 in the ). The XRD patterns indicate that the structure of compound 2 can be kept after heating at 120 °C, and the structure transformation occurs at 200 °C. Interestingly, when the calcined samples at 200 °C were suspended in water overnight, and then, the solid was filtered off and dried at room temperature, the same XRD patterns as those of the original crystal were regenerated. Thus, the dehydrated solids of these compounds may be potential reversible adsorbent materials for water molecules. Attempts to obtain the precise structures from the dehydrated crystals by single-crystal X-ray diffraction were unsuccessful, attributed to their poor crystal quality after water molecules were removed from the lattice.
elements.clean_text:
Dehydration/Hydration Study

To study the dehydration/hydration properties of these compounds, compound 2 was heated to different temperatures (120 and 200 °C) for 3 h and then was treated with water (Figure S7 in the ). The XRD patterns indicate that the structure of compound 2 can be kept after heating at 120 °C, and the structure transformation occurs at 200 °C. Interestingly, when the calcined samples at 200 °C were suspended in water overnight, and then, the solid was filtered off and dried at room temperature, the same XRD patterns as those of the original crystal were regenerated. Thus, the dehydrated solids of these compounds may be potential reversible adsorbent materials for water molecules. Attempts to obtain the precise structures from the dehydrated crystals by single-crystal X-ray diffraction were unsuccessful, attributed to their poor crystal quality after water molecules were removed from the lattice.

elements.content: Lanthanide-containing compounds are interesting luminescence materials because they emit over the entire spectral range. Especially europium-containing compound shows strong and characteristic luminescent emissions in the visible region upon excitation of ultraviolet radiation, making it good candidate materials for fluoroimmunoassays and structural probes. The solide-state luminescence properties of the Sm (4) and Eu (5) compounds were investigated at room temperature (see Table ). As illustrated in Figure , upon the excitation at 404 nm, compound 4 shows three characteristic bands for the Sm(III) ion in the range of 520–700 nm, and these emissions are attributed to 4G5/2 → 6H J (J = 5/2, 7/2, 9/2), 4G5/2 → 6H5/2 (563 nm), 4G5/2 → 6H7/2 (599 nm), and 4G5/2 → 6H9/2 (645 nm) transitions. The spectrum is dominated by the 4G5/2 → 6H7/2 transition, which gives a strong yellow luminescent output for the sample. Compound 5 shows very strong and characteristic emission spectrum of Eu(III) ions upon excitation at 396 nm (Figure ). The characteristic luminescent bands appear at 596, 616, 654, and 704 nm via the ligand-to-metal energy transfer mechanism, which correspond to the transitions from the 5D0 state to the 7F J (J = 1–4) levels, respectively. Among these transitions, the 5D0 → 7F2 transition is an electric dipole transition, which is the strongest one and results in bright red luminescence. It is documented that the intensity of the 5D0 → 7F2 transition increases as the site symmetry of Eu(III) decreases, while the 5D0 → 7F1 transition is magnetic dipole in origin and insensitive to site symmetry. Notably, the intensity of the 5D0 → 7F2 transition is about 2 times stronger than that of the 5D0 → 7F1 transition, indicating the absence of an inversion center at the Eu(III) site, which is in agreement with the single-crystal X-ray analysis. The room temperature lifetime of the excited 5D0 state of the Eu(III) ions is measured to be 0.55 ms by monitoring the 5D0 → 7F2 transitions. To identify luminescent behaviors of dehydrated samples, compound 5 will be discussed in detail as a representation (Figure ). Upon removal of the water molecules, the intensity of the emission bands and the Eu (5D0) lifetime (1.15 ms) for this dehydrated sample are enhanced greatly. The lower intensity of emission bands for the initial sample as compared with those for the corresponding dehydrated species are due to the quenching effect of the luminescent state by high-frequency vibrating water molecules. The splitting of this peak around 615 nm in the case of the dehydrated sample is probably due to the structural changes after dehydration.

Luminescent Properties

Lanthanide-containing compounds are interesting luminescence materials because they emit over the entire spectral range. Especially europium-containing compound shows strong and characteristic luminescent emissions in the visible region upon excitation of ultraviolet radiation, making it good candidate materials for fluoroimmunoassays and structural probes. The solide-state luminescence properties of the Sm (4) and Eu (5) compounds were investigated at room temperature (see Table ). As illustrated in Figure , upon the excitation at 404 nm, compound 4 shows three characteristic bands for the Sm(III) ion in the range of 520-700 nm, and these emissions are attributed to 4G5/2 → 6H J  (J = 5/2, 7/2, 9/2), 4G5/2 → 6H5/2 (563 nm), 4G5/2 → 6H7/2 (599 nm), and 4G5/2 → 6H9/2 (645 nm) transitions. The spectrum is dominated by the 4G5/2 → 6H7/2 transition, which gives a strong yellow luminescent output for the sample. Compound 5 shows very strong and characteristic emission spectrum of Eu(III) ions upon excitation at 396 nm (Figure ). The characteristic luminescent bands appear at 596, 616, 654, and 704 nm via the ligand-to-metal energy transfer mechanism, which correspond to the transitions from the 5D0 state to the 7F J  (J = 1-4) levels, respectively. Among these transitions, the 5D0 → 7F2 transition is an electric dipole transition, which is the strongest one and results in bright red luminescence. It is documented that the intensity of the 5D0 → 7F2 transition increases as the site symmetry of Eu(III) decreases, while the 5D0 → 7F1 transition is magnetic dipole in origin and insensitive to site symmetry. Notably, the intensity of the 5D0 → 7F2 transition is about 2 times stronger than that of the 5D0 → 7F1 transition, indicating the absence of an inversion center at the Eu(III) site, which is in agreement with the single-crystal X-ray analysis. The room temperature lifetime of the excited 5D0 state of the Eu(III) ions is measured to be 0.55 ms by monitoring the 5D0 → 7F2 transitions. To identify luminescent behaviors of dehydrated samples, compound 5 will be discussed in detail as a representation (Figure ). Upon removal of the water molecules, the intensity of the emission bands and the Eu (5D0) lifetime (1.15 ms) for this dehydrated sample are enhanced greatly. The lower intensity of emission bands for the initial sample as compared with those for the corresponding dehydrated species are due to the quenching effect of the luminescent state by high-frequency vibrating water molecules. The splitting of this peak around 615 nm in the case of the dehydrated sample is probably due to the structural changes after dehydration.

In summary, six novel lanthanide oxalatophosphonates with a 3D framework structure have been successfully synthesized by using the H2O3PCH2NCH2(CH2CH2OPO2H) (H3L) as the phosphonate ligand and oxalate as the second metal linker under hydrothermal conditions. Compounds 1–6 are isostructural and feature a complex 3D network built from 1D chains of lanthanide oxalate and {Ln(H2L)}2+ chains. These lanthanide oxalatophosphonates possess two types of channels with dimensions of 11.6 Å × 4.4 Å and 13.8 Å × 8.9 Å along the a- and b-axis, respectively, and these channels incorporate some crystalline water molecules therein by hydrogen-bonding interactions. Topologically, the whole structure can be viewed as a rarely observed noninterpenetrated (3,5) net. Thermal stabilities and dehydration/hydration properties of compound 2 have been investigated. Our studies show that the dehydrated solids of these compounds may be potential reversible adsorbent materials for water molecules. Additionally, luminescent properties of compounds 4 and 5 have also been studied. Compound 4 is a good candidate for yellow-light luminescent material, and compound 5 is capable of producing red light in electroluminescent devices.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, six novel lanthanide oxalatophosphonates with a 3D framework structure have been successfully synthesized by using the H2O3PCH2NCH2(CH2CH2OPO2H) (H3L) as the phosphonate ligand and oxalate as the second metal linker under hydrothermal conditions. Compounds 1-6 are isostructural and feature a complex 3D network built from 1D chains of lanthanide oxalate and {Ln(H2L)}2+ chains. These lanthanide oxalatophosphonates possess two types of channels with dimensions of 11.6 Å × 4.4 Å and 13.8 Å × 8.9 Å along the a- and b-axis, respectively, and these channels incorporate some crystalline water molecules therein by hydrogen-bonding interactions. Topologically, the whole structure can be viewed as a rarely observed noninterpenetrated (3,5) net. Thermal stabilities and dehydration/hydration properties of compound 2 have been investigated. Our studies show that the dehydrated solids of these compounds may be potential reversible adsorbent materials for water molecules. Additionally, luminescent properties of compounds 4 and 5 have also been studied. Compound 4 is a good candidate for yellow-light luminescent material, and compound 5 is capable of producing red light in electroluminescent devices.

Synthesis of {[Ce(H2L)(C2O4)(H2O)]⋅3H2O}∞ (1)

A mixture of CeCl3⋅7H2O (0.19 g, 0.5 mmol), H3L (0.26 g, 1.0 mmol), H2C2O4⋅2H2O (0.25 g, 2.0 mmol), and NaOH (0.08 g, 2.0 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of distilled water. The resulting solution was stirred for about 1 h at room temperature, sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, and then heated at 180 °C for 4 days. After the mixture was cooled slowly to room temperature, the colorless block crystals were obtained. Yield: 61.2% based on Ce. Anal. calcd for C6H18NO14P2Ce: C, 13.59; H, 3.42; N, 2.64; P, 11.68; Ce, 26.42. Found: C, 13.65; H, 3.46; N, 2.68; P, 11.61; Ce, 26.38%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3433 (br), 2923 (w), 2715 (w), 2586 (w), 2462 (w), 1670 (w), 1633 (w), 1596 (w), 1474 (w), 1449 (w), 1418 (w), 1320 (m), 1247 (s), 1203 (m), 1166 (s), 1105 (m), 1086 (m), 1056 (s), 1018 (m), 958 (m), 927 (m), 859 (w), 797 (m), 596 (w), 552 (w), 508 (w), 478 (s).

Synthesis of {[Pr(H2L)(C2O4)(H2O)]⋅3H2O}∞ (2)

Compound 2 was synthesized by a method similar to that of compound 1, using PrCl3⋅6H2O (0.18 g, 0.50 mmol) instead of CeCl3⋅7H2O as the starting material. After the mixture was cooled slowly to room temperature, the green block crystals were obtained. Yield: 62.5% based on Pr. Anal. calcd for C6H18NO14P2Pr: C, 13.57; H, 3.42; N, 2.64; P, 11.66; Pr, 26.53. Found: C, 13.63; H, 3.48; N, 2.60; P, 11.70; Pr, 26.48%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3409 (br), 3017 (w), 2960 (w), 2705 (w), 2592 (w), 2475 (w), 1670 (w), 1634 (w), 1596 (w), 1480 (w), 1448 (w), 1418 (w), 1320 (m), 1253 (s), 1203 (m), 1166 (s), 1080 (s), 1056 (s), 1018 (m), 958 (m), 920 (m), 853 (w), 797 (s), 596 (w), 552 (w), 516 (w), 478 (m).

Synthesis of {[Nd(H2L)(C2O4)(H2O)]⋅3H2O}∞ (3)

Compound 3 was synthesized by a method similar to that of compound 1, using NdCl3⋅6H2O (0.18 g, 0.50 mmol) instead of CeCl3⋅7H2O as the starting material. After the mixture was cooled slowly to room temperature, the purple block crystals were obtained. Yield: 58.8% based on Nd. Anal. calcd for C6H18NO14P2Nd: C, 13.49; H, 3.40; N, 2.62; P, 11.59; Nd, 26.99. Found: C, 13.43; H, 3.45; N, 2.68; P, 11.53; Nd, 27.05%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3562 (w), 3403 (br), 3010 (w), 2960 (w), 2715 (w), 2591 (w), 2481 (w), 1664 (w), 1602 (w), 1480 (m), 1442 (m), 1424 (m), 1320 (s), 1253 (s), 1203 (s), 1165 (s), 1092 (s), 1050 (s), 1018 (s), 964 (s), 927 (s), 852 (m), 791 (s), 601 (m), 552 (m), 516 (m), 478 (s), 417 (m).

Synthesis of {[Sm(H2L)(C2O4)(H2O)]⋅2H2O}∞ (4)

Compound 4 was synthesized by a method similar to that of compound 1, using SmCl3⋅6H2O (0.18 g, 0.50 mmol) instead of CeCl3⋅7H2O as the starting material. After the mixture was cooled slowly to room temperature, the colorless block crystals were obtained. Yield: 60.8% based on Sm. Anal. calcd for C6H16NO13P2Sm: C, 13.79; H, 3.09; N, 2.68; P, 11.86; Sm, 28.78. Found: C, 13.73; H, 3.15; N, 2.73; P, 11.81; Sm, 28.85%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3562 (w), 3402 (br), 3016 (w), 2960 (w), 2715 (w), 2592 (w), 2475 (w), 1663 (s), 1608 (s), 1480 (w), 1449 (w), 1424 (w), 1320 (s), 1259 (s), 1203 (s), 1173 (s), 1112 (s), 1086 (s), 1050 (s), 1018 (m), 958 (m), 927 (m), 852 (w), 797 (s), 602 (w), 552 (w), 508 (w), 478 (m), 417 (w).

Synthesis of {[Eu(H2L)(C2O4)(H2O)]⋅2H2O}∞ (5)

Compound 5 was synthesized by a method similar to that of compound 1, using EuCl3⋅6H2O (0.18 g, 0.50 mmol) instead of CeCl3⋅7H2O as the starting material. After the mixture was cooled slowly to room temperature, the colorless block crystals were obtained. Yield: 63.3% based on Eu. Anal. calcd for C6H16NO13P2Eu: C, 13.75; H, 3.08; N, 2.67; P, 11.82; Eu, 29.00. Found: C, 13.70; H, 3.13; N, 2.63; P, 11.87; Eu, 28.95%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3586 (w), 3476 (br), 2936 (w), 2586 (w), 2474 (w), 1639 (s), 1560 (w), 1474 (w), 1449 (m), 1418 (w), 1320 (s), 1247 (s), 1203 (s), 1173 (s), 1111 (s), 1086 (s), 1056 (s), 1018 (s), 952 (m), 927 (s), 859 (w), 805 (s), 596 (m), 552 (m), 508 (m), 478 (m), 416 (w).

Synthesis of {[Tb(H2L)(C2O4)(H2O)]⋅2H2O}∞ (6)

A mixture of TbCl3⋅6H2O (0.09 g, 0.25 mmol), H3L (0.13 g, 0.5 mmol), H2C2O4⋅2H2O (0.25 g, 2.0 mmol) and NaOH (0.08 g, 2.0 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of distilled water. The resulting solution was stirred for about 1 h at room temperature, sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, and then heated at 120 °C for 4 days. After the mixture was cooled slowly to room temperature, the colorless block crystals were obtained. Only the crystal structure for compound 6 was recorded; its TG analyses, IR spectroscopy, luminescence spectroscopy, elemental analysis, and XRD powder diffraction studies were not performed due to insufficient sample available.

cln_elements.content:
Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out in the interest of studying the thermal behaviors of the open-framework polymer materials. The experiments were performed in static air for crystalline samples of compounds 1–5 in the temperature range from 50 to 1100 °C. Compounds 1–5 show similar thermal decomposition process with four main continuous weight losses. Herein, we use compound 2 as an example to illuminate the weight losses in detail (Figure S3 in the ). The water molecules are released in two steps. The first step started at 50 °C and was completed at 105 °C, corresponding to the release of one water molecule. A weight loss of 3.1% is observed, which is in good agreement with the calculated value (3.4%). The remaining three water molecules are released up to 200 °C, and the observed weight loss of 7.8% is smaller than the calculated value (10.1%). The third step, from 340 to 405 °C, corresponds to the partly decomposition of oxalate and phosphonate units. The fourth step covers a temperature range from 965 to 1020 °C, which can be attributed to the further decomposition of the organic groups in the framework, leaving purely inorganic praseodymium phosphate network. The final product of the thermal process is the mixture of Pr(PO3)3 and PrPO4 on the basis of powder X-ray diffraction (Figure S4 in the ). The total weight loss of 40.7% is slightly smaller than the calculated value (42.2%).

Luminescent Properties

Lanthanide-containing compounds are interesting luminescence materials because they emit over the entire spectral range. Especially europium-containing compound shows strong and characteristic luminescent emissions in the visible region upon excitation of ultraviolet radiation, making it good candidate materials for fluoroimmunoassays and structural probes. The solide-state luminescence properties of the Sm (4) and Eu (5) compounds were investigated at room temperature (see Table ). As illustrated in Figure , upon the excitation at 404 nm, compound 4 shows three characteristic bands for the Sm(III) ion in the range of 520–700 nm, and these emissions are attributed to 4G5/2 → 6H J (J = 5/2, 7/2, 9/2), 4G5/2 → 6H5/2 (563 nm), 4G5/2 → 6H7/2 (599 nm), and 4G5/2 → 6H9/2 (645 nm) transitions. The spectrum is dominated by the 4G5/2 → 6H7/2 transition, which gives a strong yellow luminescent output for the sample. Compound 5 shows very strong and characteristic emission spectrum of Eu(III) ions upon excitation at 396 nm (Figure ). The characteristic luminescent bands appear at 596, 616, 654, and 704 nm via the ligand-to-metal energy transfer mechanism, which correspond to the transitions from the 5D0 state to the 7F J (J = 1–4) levels, respectively. Among these transitions, the 5D0 → 7F2 transition is an electric dipole transition, which is the strongest one and results in bright red luminescence. It is documented that the intensity of the 5D0 → 7F2 transition increases as the site symmetry of Eu(III) decreases, while the 5D0 → 7F1 transition is magnetic dipole in origin and insensitive to site symmetry. Notably, the intensity of the 5D0 → 7F2 transition is about 2 times stronger than that of the 5D0 → 7F1 transition, indicating the absence of an inversion center at the Eu(III) site, which is in agreement with the single-crystal X-ray analysis. The room temperature lifetime of the excited 5D0 state of the Eu(III) ions is measured to be 0.55 ms by monitoring the 5D0 → 7F2 transitions. To identify luminescent behaviors of dehydrated samples, compound 5 will be discussed in detail as a representation (Figure ). Upon removal of the water molecules, the intensity of the emission bands and the Eu (5D0) lifetime (1.15 ms) for this dehydrated sample are enhanced greatly. The lower intensity of emission bands for the initial sample as compared with those for the corresponding dehydrated species are due to the quenching effect of the luminescent state by high-frequency vibrating water molecules. The splitting of this peak around 615 nm in the case of the dehydrated sample is probably due to the structural changes after dehydration.
